title: LGPL-3.0 license usage of sharp dependencies blocks us from using Next 15

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Image (next/image)
labels.description: Related to Next.js Image Optimization.

labels.name: invalid link
labels.description: The issue was auto-closed due to a missing/invalid reproduction link. A new issue should be opened.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/vercel/next.js

### To Reproduce

Since sharp was getting a direct dependency of Next.js we now have legal issues from using Next.js v15.
Our company-set pipeline license checker action (snyk) automatically stops the PR validation and stops us from upgrading to v15.

list of affected deps:
```
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linux-x64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linux-x64@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linux-arm@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linux-arm@1.0.5
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-darwin-x64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-darwin-x64@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linux-arm64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linux-arm64@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linux-s390x@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linux-s390x@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-darwin-arm64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-darwin-arm64@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linuxmusl-x64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linuxmusl-x64@1.0.4
 next@15.0.2 › sharp@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-linuxmusl-arm64@0.33.5 › @img/sharp-libvips-linuxmusl-arm64@1.0.4
```

 I already started conversation about it with legal department, but what I get so far is:

> The LGPL-3.0 (Lesser General Public License) is a concern mainly due to how it governs usage, distribution, and modifications of libraries within other software. Specifically:
> 
> - Copyleft Requirements: LGPL-3.0 is a "weak copyleft" license, meaning that if you modify the LGPL-licensed library itself, you must release those modifications under the same LGPL license. However, you don't have to release the entire codebase under LGPL—only the changes to the LGPL-licensed library.
> - Distribution Implications: If you distribute software that statically links or tightly integrates with LGPL-licensed code, you might need to provide users with access to the library source code and instructions on how they could replace it in your application. In a frontend context, this could potentially mean offering a way for end-users to swap out the LGPL library in your distributed code, which can be challenging in web apps.
> - Compatibility with Commercial Use: Many companies avoid LGPL in commercial software because of the obligation to share library modifications and the potential complications if they want to embed or redistribute the code in products.

I'm not a lawyer so I'm not sure how to handle this case but from my understanding, Next.js shouldn't have this kind of dependencies.
please help!

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Next.js shouldn't have a dependency with LGPL-3.0 license

### Provide environment information

```bash
Next.js 15.x
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Image (next/image)

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Other (Deployed)

### Additional context

_No response_

title: "use cache" cannot call function from inside closure

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: dynamicIO
labels.description: Related to dynamicIO.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/romeovs/use-cached-closures-repro

### To Reproduce

1. `next dev`
2. open <http://localhost:3000>

There will be the error:
```
[ Server ] Error: generate is not defined
```
3. edit `app/page.tsx` to use `../api/direct` instead of `../api/closure`
4. open <http://localhost:3000>, there will be no errors

### Current vs. Expected behavior

`"use cache"` should work inside functions closures, and should be able to use closed over values. This will help with wrapping third-party clients with a Next.js cache.

```
function defineClient() {
  function handler() {
    // from a library
    return client.fetch()
  }

  async function get() {
    "use cache"
     // this should be able to call handler but it fails
     return await handler()
  }

  return { get }
}
```

If that's not possible for some reason, I would like the Next.js compiler to make it clear in the error message and this should be documented somewhere. It would also seriously reduce the usefulness of the `"use cache"` pattern.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/chungweileong94/nextjs-server-action-async-func-bug

### To Reproduce

1. Start the server, `pnpm dev`
2. Navigate to the homepage

### Current vs. Expected behavior

**Expected:**
-  No error

**Current**
- "Server Actions must be async functions." error will shows up, but incorrectly.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 24.1.0: Thu Oct 10 21:05:14 PDT 2024; root:xnu-11215.41.3~2/RELEASE_ARM64_T8103
  Available memory (MB): 16384
  Available CPU cores: 8
Binaries:
  Node: 20.12.0
  npm: 10.5.0
  Yarn: 1.22.21
  pnpm: 8.15.7
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.3-canary.6 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.3-canary.6).
  eslint-config-next: N/A
  react: 19.0.0-rc-7c8e5e7a-20241101
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-7c8e5e7a-20241101
  typescript: 5.3.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Not sure

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local), next build (local)

### Additional context

I'm an author of a small library called [server-act](https://github.com/chungweileong94/server-act), which the library is a simple server action builder by using the function builder pattern to construct a server action, like
```ts
const action = builder
  .input(...)
  .action(...);
```

However, since Next.js 15, Next.js failed to detect the async function/server action correctly. For instance:
```ts
export const action = builder
  .input(() => { ... }) // <-- Next.js keeps saying that this needs to be an async function, message: "Server Actions must be async functions."
  .action(...); // <-- this will always return an async function, aka server action
```

The same thing happens to one of the similar library as well, https://github.com/TheEdoRan/next-safe-action/issues/288.

title: Cookies are not immedietly set when setting them in middleware, and reading them in page

labels.name: create-next-app
labels.description: Related to our CLI tool for quickly starting a new Next.js application.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Middleware
labels.description: Related to Next.js Middleware.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://github.com/shared-on-forums/next-cookie-unexpected ### To Reproduce In my real application, I am trying to see if the user is logged in or not, if the user is logged in, I will show him a LOGOUT button. If he is not logged in, I want to show him a LOGIN button. But I am getting a problem, that the cookie first time is being undefined when reading it, although it exists, the second time, it is there. I made a reproducible example here: I am trying to set a cookie in `middleware.ts` file, then I am trying to read it (for demo in this simple reproducible code) in one of the pages. This is a nextjs15 project with app router. All with server components. I am setting a cookie in middleware.ts, and I am making sure the cookie is ALWAYS set and there. Then In a page, In a nested server component, I am trying to read that cookie once again. But, I am getting `undefined`! I open my browser, open dev tools, navigated to the cookies section, then, request localhost:3000, (my application). a cookie gets in, but in the page, the cookie value isn't printed, I am getting (cookie is UNDEFINED). This only happens the first time, but if you refresh the page, subsequent requests will see the cookie value and it works. Look at the demo here: [![enter image description here][1]][1] Folder: ``` . ├── bun.lockb ├── next.config.ts ├── next-env.d.ts ├── package.json ├── src │   ├── app │   │   ├── cookie-block.tsx │   │   ├── layout.tsx │   │   └── page.tsx │   ├── functions │   │   └── auth-cookie.ts │   └── middleware.ts └── tsconfig.json ``` ## File: src/middleware.ts ```typescript import { NextResponse } from 'next/server' import { getAuthCookie, setAuthCookie } from './functions/auth-cookie' export default async function middleware() { // # ensure cookie exists const authToken = await getAuthCookie() if (!authToken) await setAuthCookie() return NextResponse.next() } export const config = { matcher: '/((?!_next/static|favicon.ico).*)', } ``` ## File: src/functions/auth-cookie.ts ```typescript import { cookies } from 'next/headers' const COOKIE_NAME = 'auth' export const setAuthCookie = async () => { const cookieStore = await cookies() const hardcodedValue = 'abcd123' cookieStore.set(COOKIE_NAME, hardcodedValue, {}) } export const getAuthCookie = async () => { const cookieStore = await cookies() const cookie = cookieStore.get(COOKIE_NAME) return cookie?.value } ``` ## File: src/app/page.tsx ```jsx import { CookieBlock } from './cookie-block' export default function Home() { return (

This page is just for demo

) } ``` ## File: src/app/cookie-block.tsx ```jsx import { getAuthCookie } from '@/functions/auth-cookie' export const CookieBlock = async () => { const authToken = await getAuthCookie() return (

Your cookie is:

{authToken ?? 'IT IS UNDEFINED'}

) } ``` [1]: https://i.sstatic.net/wsR7AnY8.gif ### Current vs. Expected behavior I expect it to work. But it doesn't. I found the solution to this by completly not using the ``` import { cookies } from 'next/headers' ``` package, because idk maybe only for this case, it is useless. I used this directly instead and it worked ```ts // # middleware.ts export default async function middleware() { // # ensure cookie exists const res = NextResponse.next() const authToken = await getAuthCookie() if (!authToken) setAuthCookie(res) // 👈 pass the res, no need for async/await return res // 👈 return the res } ``` ```ts // # auth-cookie.ts const COOKIE_NAME = 'auth' export const setAuthCookie = (res: NextResponse) => { const hardcodedValue = 'abcd123' return res.cookies.set(COOKIE_NAME, hardcodedValue, {}) } ``` ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: linux Arch: x64 Version: #134-Ubuntu SMP Fri Sep 27 20:20:17 UTC 2024 Available memory (MB): 15931 Available CPU cores: 4 Binaries: Node: 20.16.0 npm: 10.8.1 Yarn: N/A pnpm: 9.9.0 Relevant Packages: next: 15.0.2 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.2). eslint-config-next: 15.0.2 react: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028 react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028 typescript: 5.6.3 Next.js Config: output: N/A ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) Not sure, create-next-app, Middleware ### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) next dev (local) ### Additional context Question is also asked on Stackoverflow here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/79157823/cookies-are-not-immedietly-set-when-setting-them-in-middleware-and-reading-them I added for you two branches in the github repo, one for showing the problem, and one showing the solution of the problem.

title: Syntax error in ppr-navigations.js

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Runtime
labels.description: Related to Node.js or Edge Runtime with Next.js.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/JackatDJL/Athenetz-SV/tree/v0.0.2-dev

### To Reproduce

1. Clone the Repository
2. yarn build

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Current behavior:
While fixing another (i think non nextjs) issue
```
node:async_hooks
Module build failed: UnhandledSchemeError: Reading from "node:async_hooks" is not handled by plugins (Unhandled scheme).
Webpack supports "data:" and "file:" URIs by default.
```
by tweaking webpack
```
...
config.module.rules.push({
      test: /\.js$/,
      loader: 'string-replace-loader',
      options: {
        search: 'node:',
        replace: '',
      },
});
...
```
yarn build suddently reports a syntax error:
```
$ yarn build
   ▲ Next.js 15.0.2
   - Environments: .env.local

   Creating an optimized production build ...
Failed to compile.

./node_modules/next/dist/client/components/router-reducer/ppr-navigations.js
Error:   × An object member cannot be declared optional
     ╭─[D:\dev\Athenetz-SV\node_modules\next\dist\client\components\router-reducer\ppr-navigations.js:168:1]
 165 │         route: patchRouterStateWithNewChildren(newRouterState, patchedRouterStateChildren),
 166 │         // Only return the new cache node if there are pending tasks that need to be resolved
 167 │         // by the dynamic data from the server. If they don't, we don't need to trigger 
a dynamic request.
 168 │          needsDynamicRequest ? newCacheNode : null,
     ·                              ─
 169 │         children: taskChildren
 170 │     };
 171 │ }
     ╰────
  × Unexpected token `newCacheNode`. Expected ... , *,  (, [, :, , ?, = or an identifier       
     ╭─[D:\dev\Athenetz-SV\node_modules\next\dist\client\components\router-reducer\ppr-navigations.js:168:1]
 165 │         route: patchRouterStateWithNewChildren(newRouterState, patchedRouterStateChildren),
 166 │         // Only return the new cache node if there are pending tasks that need to be resolved
 167 │         // by the dynamic data from the server. If they don't, we don't need to trigger 
a dynamic request.
 168 │          needsDynamicRequest ? newCacheNode : null,
     ·                                ────────────
 169 │         children: taskChildren
 170 │     };
 171 │ }
     ╰────

Caused by:
    Syntax Error

Import trace for requested module:
./node_modules/next/dist/client/components/router-reducer/ppr-navigations.js
./node_modules/next/dist/client/components/router-reducer/reducers/restore-reducer.js
./node_modules/next/dist/client/components/router-reducer/router-reducer.js
./node_modules/next/dist/shared/lib/router/action-queue.js
./node_modules/next/dist/client/app-index.js


> Build failed because of webpack errors
```
after some time i fixed it (localy) by rewriting a part of ppr-navigations.js (dist)
before:
```
return {
        // Return a cloned copy of the router state with updated children.
        route: patchRouterStateWithNewChildren(newRouterState, patchedRouterStateChildren),
        // Only return the new cache node if there are pending tasks that need to be resolved
        // by the dynamic data from the server. If they don't, we don't need to trigger a dynamic request.
        node: needsDynamicRequest ? newCacheNode : null,
        children: taskChildren
    };
```
after:
```
function newCacheNodeNeeded() {
        if (needsDynamicRequest) {
            return newCacheNode;
        } else {
            return null;
        }
    }

    const isNewCacheNodeNeeded = newCacheNodeNeeded();
    return {
        // Return a cloned copy of the router state with updated children.
        route: patchRouterStateWithNewChildren(newRouterState, patchedRouterStateChildren),
        // Only return the new cache node if there are pending tasks that need to be resolved
        // by the dynamic data from the server. If they don't, we don't need to trigger a dynamic request.
        node: isNewCacheNodeNeeded
    };
```
test before:
syntax error (mentioned above / didnt want to paste again)

test after:
```
$ yarn build
   ▲ Next.js 15.0.2
   - Environments: .env.local

   Creating an optimized production build ...
 ✓ Compiled successfully

labels.description: Related to Turbopack with Next.js.

labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Turbopack team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/gnillev/next-turbo-error-reproducible

### To Reproduce


1. Run npm run dev-turbo
2. Go to `http://localhost:3005`
3. Click the button and see the error:
```
Pako error: invalid distance too far back
    at listpack (index.js:2621:15)
    at async GitPackIndex.fromPack (index.js:2821:5)
    at async _fetch (index.js:8296:17)
    at async _clone (index.js:8419:42)
    at async Object.clone (index.js:8545:12)
    at async gitCloneAndPull (page.tsx:125:7)
 ```

It doesn't fail, if you run without turbopack.
 
 Digging a bit, the error comes inside `pako`s `inflate` function, due to the following code that is deemed unreachable in the turbo compiled code, but is in fact called (and required, to initialize the window "buffer"):
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f3673146-da71-4729-a236-2133bc9edf1c)


### Current vs. Expected behavior

Following the previous steps, I expected it to be able to clone and pull from the repo (as can be seen, when running without turbopack).

title: waitUntil not working for Remix.run apps ?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Performance
labels.description: Anything with regards to Next.js performance.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/laimonassutkus/VercelWaitUntilRemixExample

### To Reproduce

1. Create a new Remix.run app.
2. Create a route with **loader** and **action** methods.
3. Create a separate logging.tsx file that is not part of the routes.
4. Inside logging.tsx has a synchronous method info and an asynchronous method that actually logs to console.
5. Asynchronous method call is wrapped with the waitUntil method.
6. Using the logger in a route e.g. logger.info("Hello") does not work - waitUntil does not make the serverless function to not exit.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

- Console.log not getting called.
- Console.log is getting called.

### Provide environment information

```bash
- Remix.run
- Typescript
- Deploying on Vercel with waitUntil

- LOCALLY IT WORKS SUPER FINE WITHOUT BUGS !!!
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Performance

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Vercel (Deployed)

### Additional context

```typescript
import { waitUntil } from "@vercel/functions"

async function asyncLog(log: string) {

    // We force the log to be printed only after some time.
    // Most importantly - AFTER the response is given.
    await new Promise(resolve => {
        setTimeout(resolve, 10_000)
    })

    console.log(log)
}

export default function info(log: string) {
    waitUntil(asyncLog(log))
}
```

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/khuezy/dynamiio_bug

### To Reproduce

Instructions in the repo:

1. npm i && npm run dev
2. go to http://localhost:3000
3. Open up developer console to see error logs
4. Click alternating on the A and B link fast until you see error. You have to click under 1s for each link.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

title: Next.js v15 forcefully dropping Click ID query parameters from URLs like ?fbclid / ?gclid

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Navigation
labels.description: Related to Next.js linking (e.g., <Link>) and navigation.

body: ### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/strange-chandrasekhar-j59xzg?file=%2Fapp%2Fapi%2Fdemo%2Froute.ts&workspaceId=7095e953-179e-4203-beb8-355f8e3d65b4 ### To Reproduce The new Next.js version (V15) seems to perform an internal redirect or some other logic causing it to drop common click ID parameters from URLs. This also happens on API routes. It does not happen with `utm_` or any other parameters except what seem to be common click identification parameters. I suspect this was done in order to fix caching issues occuring because click IDs are commonly accidentally persisted. 1. Perform a request to a Next.js V15 site with a click parameter attached to the url, e.g.: ```/?fbclid=IwAR2F4-dbP0l7Mn1IawQQGCINEz7PYXQvwjNwB_qa2ofrHyiLjcbCRxTDMgk ``` 2. See the 307 redirect happen. 3. Be surprised for the absence of the query parameter in `searchParams`. ## Locally ## CodeSandBox ### Current vs. Expected behavior The expected behavior would be to not have odd modifications of the `searchParams`, especially not in API routes. These Click ID parameters are very important to attribute conversions accurately towards ads and for server-side Conversion and Event APIs. Stripping of the parameters is OK, as long as the `searchParams` object will contain the value of the passed query parameters. On my V14 Next.js website, this behavior does not occur. ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: darwin Arch: x64 Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.1.0: Mon Oct 9 21:27:27 PDT 2023; root:xnu-10002.41.9~6/RELEASE_X86_64 Available memory (MB): 16384 Available CPU cores: 16 Binaries: Node: 18.20.0 npm: 10.5.0 Yarn: 1.22.5 pnpm: 9.12.1 Relevant Packages: next: 15.0.0-canary.152 // There is a newer canary version (15.0.3-canary.1) available, please upgrade! eslint-config-next: 14.2.5 react: 19.0.0-rc-7771d3a7-20240827 react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-7771d3a7-20240827 typescript: 5.5.4 ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) Navigation ### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) next dev (local), next build (local), next start (local), Vercel (Deployed), Other (Deployed) ### Additional context I've also reproduced on many other websites who seem to be using Next.js V15, and they all seem to exhibit stripping of major click IDs. I am interested to know how they perform advanced event matching against conversions without using click parameters. On my V14 Next.js website, this behavior does not occur.

title: Dynamic Layout with Suspense hangs after 2nd navigation in Next 15

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://github.com/caleblloyd/next-layout-cache-bug/ ### To Reproduce ```bash npm install npm run dev ``` ## To Reproduce Navigate to [http://localhost:3000/now](http://localhost:3000/now) 1. "Now Page" loads fine initially 2. Click "Home Page" 3. Click "Now Page", it is stuck at the suspense and never makes the API call [Video of bug starting from Now Page](https://github.com/caleblloyd/next-layout-cache-bug/raw/refs/heads/main/start-from-now-page.webm) **If you start at the Home Page things work fine** Navigate to [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) 1. Click on "Now Page", it works 2. Click on "Home Page" 3. Click on "Now Page" again, it works [Video of things working starting from Home Page](https://github.com/caleblloyd/next-layout-cache-bug/raw/refs/heads/main/start-from-home-page.webm) ### Current vs. Expected behavior I am using a layout in a subdirectory of the app router. It should be dynamic because I am using `export const dynamic = 'force-dynamic'` on the layout. If I load a page that uses this layout initially, then navigate away and navigate back, it gets stuck at the `Suspense` and `LoadData` is never called again. `next dev` has the static route indicator on the page upon navigating back. If I load a page that does not use this layout initially, I can navigate to a page using the layout multiple times and it works. `next dev` does not have the static route indicator on the page. ```js import {ReactNode, Suspense} from "react" import Link from "next/link"; export const dynamic = 'force-dynamic' async function LoadData(props: { children: ReactNode }) { const response = await fetch(`http://localhost:3000/api`) const data = await response.json() as { now: number } return <> {props.children}
Got API Response at {data.now}
} export default async function Layout(props: { children: ReactNode }) { return <>
Home Page
Loading... {Date.now()}}> {props.children} } ``` ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: linux Arch: x64 Version: #45-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Fri Aug 30 12:02:04 UTC 2024 Available memory (MB): 15718 Available CPU cores: 4 Binaries: Node: 20.18.0 npm: 10.8.2 Yarn: N/A pnpm: 9.12.1 Relevant Packages: next: 15.0.3-canary.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.3-canary.1). eslint-config-next: 15.0.2 react: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028 react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028 typescript: 5.6.3 Next.js Config: output: N/A ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? https://www.npmjs.com/package/critters

critters transferred ownership to beasties and marked the package as deprecated.
As the module import is in the nextjs logic, it is a bit of work to replace the module from Nextjs end user. Changing the module could also be a breaking change, not sure what is the best approach.

title: Hydration Error in Next.js 15 with React 19 Due to cz-shortcut-listen="true" Attribute Injection from Colorzilla Extension

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/MonaAghili/Portfolio

### To Reproduce

**Description:**

After updating my Next.js application to:

- **Next.js:** 15.0.2
- **React:** 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028
- **React-DOM:** 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028

I encountered a new hydration error that was not present in previous versions. Through investigation, I discovered that the `cz-shortcut-listen="true"` attribute, added by the Colorzilla browser extension, was causing the issue.

**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Update Next.js and React versions as mentioned above.
2. Enable the Colorzilla browser extension.
3. Run the Next.js application and inspect any hydration errors.

**Findings:**

The `cz-shortcut-listen="true"` attribute injected by Colorzilla causes a mismatch during the server-client hydration process in Next.js. When Colorzilla is disabled, the hydration error resolves. However, Colorzilla is a tool we rely on heavily, and disabling it whenever using Next.js is not practical.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

**Request:**

Could the Next.js team suggest a solution or workaround to prevent this attribute from interfering with hydration without disabling Colorzilla? This would be immensely helpful for developers who rely on both Next.js and the Colorzilla extension. Thank you!

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1d993bd1-502c-4ec5-b80a-fd547497d3eb)

title: Unable to install major packages with Next.js 15 and React 19 RC

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://stackblitz.com/edit/nextjs15-react-rc-peer-dep?file=README.md

### To Reproduce

1. Open sample repro at https://stackblitz.com/edit/nextjs15-react-rc-peer-dep?file=README.md (or create a starter app with `create-next-app`)
2. Run `npm i @mui/material` or `npm i react-hook-form` in the console
3. Observe the following errors:

```shell
❯ npm i @mui/material
npm ERR! code ERESOLVE
npm ERR! ERESOLVE unable to resolve dependency tree
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! While resolving: undefined@undefined
npm ERR! Found: react@19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028
npm ERR! node_modules/react
npm ERR!   react@"19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028" from the root project
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Could not resolve dependency:
npm ERR! peer react@"^17.0.0 || ^18.0.0 || ^19.0.0" from @mui/material@6.1.5
npm ERR! node_modules/@mui/material
npm ERR!   @mui/material@"*" from the root project
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Fix the upstream dependency conflict, or retry
npm ERR! this command with --force or --legacy-peer-deps
npm ERR! to accept an incorrect (and potentially broken) dependency resolution.
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! For a full report see:
npm ERR! /home/.npm/_logs/2024-10-29T13_29_55_157Z-eresolve-report.txt
```

```shell
❯ npm i react-hook-form
npm ERR! code ERESOLVE
npm ERR! ERESOLVE unable to resolve dependency tree
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! While resolving: undefined@undefined
npm ERR! Found: react@19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028
npm ERR! node_modules/react
npm ERR!   react@"19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028" from the root project
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Could not resolve dependency:
npm ERR! peer react@"^16.8.0 || ^17 || ^18 || ^19" from react-hook-form@7.53.1
npm ERR! node_modules/react-hook-form
npm ERR!   react-hook-form@"*" from the root project
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Fix the upstream dependency conflict, or retry
npm ERR! this command with --force or --legacy-peer-deps
npm ERR! to accept an incorrect (and potentially broken) dependency resolution.
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! For a full report see:
npm ERR! /home/.npm/_logs/2024-10-29T13_29_07_240Z-eresolve-report.txt
```

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Unable to install major packages with Next.js 15 due to `react` RC peer dependency. `npm install` fails with the "Could not resolve dependency" error (see repro above).

For example, `@mui/material` uses the following React peer dependency range - `^17.0.0 || ^18.0.0 || ^19.0.0`, which fails with the React RC version installed by default from Next.js 15 peer dependencies. The same issue happens with `react-hook-form` and `^16.8.0 || ^17 || ^18 || ^19` peer dependency range, and also other packages using `>=18` peer dependency range.

I'm aware of the following workarounds, but it seems like a major inconvenience and really a blocker for inexperienced developers.

1) Install with `--legacy-peer-deps` flag:

```shell
npm i --legacy-peer-deps @mui/material
```

2) Add React version overrides to `package.json`:

```json
"overrides": {
  "@mui/material": {
    "react": "19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021",
    "react-dom": "19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021"
  }
}
```

or

```json
"overrides": {
  "react": "$react",
  "react-dom": "$react-dom"
}
```

3) Downgrade `react` to 18

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: x64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 24.0.0: Tue Sep 24 23:36:30 PDT 2024; root:xnu-11215.1.12~1/RELEASE_X86_64
  Available memory (MB): 32768
  Available CPU cores: 12
Binaries:

  npm: 10.9.0
  Yarn: N/A
  pnpm: N/A
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1).
  eslint-config-next: 15.0.1
  react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Not sure

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local), next build (local), next start (local)

### Additional context

I've also tested with the latest canary (15.0.2-canary.10) and observed the same issue.

title: Cache is always stale on startup for dynamic ISR pages

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Performance
labels.description: Anything with regards to Next.js performance.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/PeterGardenas/next-dynamic-isr-stale-on-startup

### To Reproduce

1. npm run build
2. Start next on port 3000 & 3001
3. Visit localhost:3000/bar and localhost:3001/bar

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Current behavior:
1. Initial request to /bar shows the same date. For the later of the requests `x-nextjs-cache`  header is  STALE
2. /bar is revalidate
3. When refreshing localhost:3000/bar and localhost:3001/bar will display different dates

Expected:
1. Initial request to /bar shows the same date. For the later of the requests `x-nextjs-cache`  header is  HIT
2. /bar is not modified
3. When refreshing localhost:3000/bar and localhost:3001/bar will display same dates

The expected behavior works when doing the sample example for /foo as it is provided in generateStaticParams



### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: win32
  Arch: x64
  Version: Windows 10 Enterprise
  Available memory (MB): 32466
  Available CPU cores: 16
Binaries:
  Node: 20.15.0
  npm: N/A
  Yarn: N/A
  pnpm: 8.15.4
Relevant Packages:

  eslint-config-next: N/A
  react: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-02c0e824-20241028
  typescript: 5.3.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Performance

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next build (local), next start (local)

### Additional context

This issue exists in Next 14 as well.
Using a custom cache handler such as [redis-handler](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/tree/canary/examples/cache-handler-redis) resolves the issue of diverging content, the content is still unnecessarily revalidate, causing redundant computation.

A naive debugging attempt indicates that https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/97153cc838d24c58c13f583f1d88f21b30a8621a/packages/next/src/server/lib/incremental-cache/index.ts#L223 always return 1 as this.revalidateTimings is not set for isr dynamic routes

title: Error: Cannot await or return from a thenable

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/rafzan/thenable-error

### To Reproduce

1. Get to root and try to build the application. You should get `Error: Cannot await or return from a thenable`

### Current vs. Expected behavior

The application should build, like in prior versions.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 24.0.0: Tue Sep 24 23:37:25 PDT 2024; root:xnu-11215.1.12~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6030
  Available memory (MB): 18432
  Available CPU cores: 11
Binaries:
  Node: 20.13.1
  npm: 10.5.2
  Yarn: 1.22.22
  pnpm: N/A
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1).
  eslint-config-next: 15.0.1
  react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next build (local)

### Additional context

https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/optimizing/lazy-loading

Docs suggest that in order to use `dynamic()` imports with named exports we should use `import('../components/hello').then((mod) => mod.Hello)`

By importing a `client` component from a `server` component using this pattern for named exports, you get `Error: Cannot await or return from a thenable`. I'm opening this issue  mainly because you get no information whatsoever by searching online yet.

I'd expect either the documentation to explicitly tell that you shouldn't use this pattern on this scenario, or better yet, that docs provided a viable pattern to be used when importing `client` from `server` via named exports.

As a quick fix, I just separated every component into its own file and `export default` each one, thus removing the need for `.then`

title: Can't purge cache with hard refresh when using "use cache"

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/mordechaim/next-repro-cache-refresh

### To Reproduce

1. Start the application in dev mode
2. Observe the dates being cached in 2 different modes
3. Open devtools
4. Right click the browser refresh button
5. Choose "Empty Cache and Hard Reload"

Hard reload allows us to purge the cache in development which is a crucial feature when making changes to a cached function.

title: Unable to configure webpack dev server.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Webpack
labels.description: Related to Webpack with Next.js.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Related to Next.js' official documentation.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/dwjohnston/nextjs-webpack-dev-server

### To Reproduce

1. Start the application (npm run dev), open browser window to running application
2. Open the dev tools, network tab, inspect the headers of the page.js file 

The reproduction attempts to configure the webpack dev server by adding: 

```
  webpack: (config) => {
    if (!config.devServer){
      config.devServer = {};
    }

    config.devServer.headers = () => {
      return [{
        key: "hello", 
        value: "world"
      }]
    }
    return config;   
  }
```

To next.config.js


The [NextJS documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/next-config-js/webpack) does not indicate that webpack dev server can not be configured this way, nor does it indicate an alternative mechanism for configuring.  

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Expected behaviour: 

The `page.js` resource should have the header `hello: world'

Actual behaviour: 

The resouce does not have the expected header. 



### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.6.0: Wed Jul 31 20:49:39 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.141.1.700.5~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6000
  Available memory (MB): 32768
  Available CPU cores: 8
Binaries:
  Node: 22.10.0
  npm: 10.9.0
  Yarn: 1.22.22
  pnpm: 8.9.0
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1).
  eslint-config-next: 15.0.1
  react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Developer Experience, Documentation, Webpack

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local)

### Additional context

The purpose of this, is investigating a performance optimisation - basically implementing something similar to [Vite's prebundling](https://vite.dev/guide/dep-pre-bundling). 

The issue I have is our development bundle is very large (15MB or so) and this takes about 1-2s to download. I want to use Webpack's [SplitChunksPlugin](https://webpack.js.org/plugins/split-chunks-plugin/#splitchunkscachegroups) to split out large vendor bundles, and also apply an immutable cache header to them. 

The webpack configuration for splitting the chunks is being respected, but I can't apply the immutable cache header.

title: Turbopack assigning class variables as undefined explicitly on construction.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: TypeScript
labels.description: Related to types with Next.js.

labels.name: Turbopack
labels.description: Related to Turbopack with Next.js.

labels.name: linear: turbopack
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Turbopack team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/max-widmaier/turbopack-explicit-undefined

### To Reproduce

1, Create a basic Next app
2. In src/app/page.tsx (jsx) use the following:

```typescript
class MyClass {
    public someProperty?: string;

    constructor() {
    }
}

export default function Page() {
    console.log(new MyClass());

    return <>Hello World</>
}
```

3. Run using `next dev`
4. Output will be
```javascript
MyClass {} // someProperty is implicitly undefined
```
5. Run using `next dev --turbo`
6. Output will be
```javascript
MyClass {
    someProperty: undefined // EXPLICIT UNDEFINED
}
```

### Current vs. Expected behavior

First for some background. I'm writing things with decorators to override get/set functionality of class properties. As part of this I've had to assign the property internally to `~${propertyName}` 
So assigning myObj.someProperty = 1234 and then console.logging myObj would give you:

```json
{
  "~someProperty": 1234
}
```

However, if "someProperty" is _explicity_ set to undefined, then the getter is overriden to get that undefined value. Normally, this is impossible because of the setter being overriden.

Doing otherwise leads to stackoverflows (assigning and then assigning and so on).

So, say I have my class:
```typescript
export class MyClass {
   @getSetOverride public someProperty?: number | null; 
}
```

Using the following code in a basic Next using Turbopack results in some unintended functionality (I used a page.tsx in the app router):

```typescript
export default function MyPage() {
   const myObj = new MyClass();
   myObj.someProperty = 1234;
   console.log(myObj);
}
```

The log results in:
```javascript
{
    someProperty: undefined,
    "~someProperty": 1234
}
```

Running `myObj.someProperty` then gives `undefined`.

Running the same code without Turbopack gives the proper value and the output is

```json
{
  "~someProperty": 1234
}
```

My assumption is that Turbopack is explicitly assigning class variables as undefined rather leaving them implicitly undefined.

You know you're doing something obscure when the build tool causes bugs...

TL;DR I would class instantiation to leave class field _implicitly_ undefined rather than _explicitly_ undefined. I have not assigned the fields to undefined so those fields shouldn't be touched.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: win32
  Arch: x64
  Version: Windows 10 Home
  Available memory (MB): 32666
  Available CPU cores: 16
Binaries:
  Node: 20.9.0
  npm: N/A
  Yarn: N/A
  pnpm: N/A
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1).
  eslint-config-next: 14.2.13
  react: 18.3.1
  react-dom: 18.3.1
  typescript: 5.6.2
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```

Turbopack

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

### Additional context

Tested on Next 14.2.13 and Next 15.0.1

title: Unclear caching behavior in nextjs 14 and 15

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/mastoj/wrapped-fetch-debug

### To Reproduce

I have the exact same app in nextjs 14: https://github.com/mastoj/wrapped-fetch-bug-14 and nextjs 15: https://github.com/mastoj/wrapped-fetch-debug

What we are doing is testing what is happening when you wrap fetch in a higher order function, since that is a natural way to componse functions together.

Both of the solution is not behaving as I expect them to. To reproduce the issue in any of the repos do:

1. `pnpm run build`
2. `pnpm run start`
3. http://localhost:3000/debug
4. http://localhost:3000/debug

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Doing the first load will print the logs from the api/route:

> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/1
> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/2
> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/3

which is as expected. Doing the second load of the page is what makes things interesting. In our `/debug` page we are making three api-calls in a slightly different way, but I expect them all to be cached.

## Nextjs 14 behavior

For some reason the fetch call that is wrapped using a higher order function won't cache at all and we get the following output: 

> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/2

## Nextjs 15 behavior

In 15 the behavior differed quite a lot from 14. To some degree it make sense since the defaults has changed. Since we are using explicit `const dynamic` and `revalidate` on fetch I would actually expect the behavior to be the same, but that is not the case. In 15 it seems like nothing is cached and we make api calls every time.

> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/1
> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/2
> ==> Getting some data:  /api/data/3

## Expected behavior

Even though we have `export const dynamic = "force-dynamic"` I would expect the `revalidate` on the fetch calls to be honored. That assumptions means I would expect no outputs from the log from the routes to be outputted since no calls should be made.

body: ### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/nice-bose-p9y9lt?workspaceId=8c42ce9b-a788-4790-894d-50229e1eadea ### To Reproduce The codesandbox is a simplified setup of our site and config. This should be run with domain routing. ### Current vs. Expected behavior In the example code, the link components that are resolved on the server, get the default locale as an infix. An example of where this happens is on [diamondsbyme.com/rings/](https://www.diamondsbyme.com/rings/). The menu and product links are structured as a relative link with the locale, even if it is the default locale (en) for that domain, resulting in the link being `https://www.diamondsbyme.com/en/rings/`. This should just resolve to `https://www.diamondsbyme.com/rings/` on the server, as it did previously. On previous deployments this behavior wasn't present. When the link is resolved via client side routing, the default locale is not present in the href. This can be tested on the example link by navigating via the menu to, for example, “Men's rings”. The products will change and not have the default locale infix in the href, it even is the complete URL. Refreshing the page will include the default locale again as a relative link. I've downgraded to 14.2.10 and even to 14.2.3 but the issue still persists. ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: darwin Arch: x64 Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.6.0: Mon Jul 29 21:13:00 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.141.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64 Available memory (MB): 40960 Available CPU cores: 16 Binaries: Node: 21.6.2 npm: 10.2.4 Yarn: 1.22.22 pnpm: 9.12.2 Relevant Packages: next: 14.2.10 // An outdated version detected (latest is 15.0.1), upgrade is highly recommended! eslint-config-next: 14.2.3 react: 18.2.0 react-dom: 18.2.0 typescript: N/A Next.js Config: output: N/A ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? title: Fallback rewrites do not trigger after calling `notFound` function in dynamic route

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Runtime
labels.description: Related to Node.js or Edge Runtime with Next.js.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/jplwood/nextjs-rewrite-notfound-repro

### To Reproduce

1. start the application with `npm run dev`

**Demonstrate the fallback rewrite:**

3. go to home route [https://localhost:3000/home](https://localhost:3000/home) 👉 page loads ✅ 
4. go to random route under home [https://localhost:3000/home/rewriteworks](https://localhost:3000/home/rewriteworks) 👉 rewrite to google is triggered ✅ 

**Demonstrate fallback not working**

5. go to dynamic route [https://localhost:3000/exists](https://localhost:3000/exists) 👉  page loads ✅ 
6. go to dynamic route again to trigger not found [https://localhost:3000/rewrites](https://localhost:3000/rewrites) 👉 page rewrite is not triggered, 404 page is shown ❌ 


### Current vs. Expected behavior

Per [rewrite docs](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/next-config-js/rewrites):

> 6. fallback rewrites are checked/applied, these are applied before rendering the 404 page and after dynamic routes/all static assets have been checked.  [source](https://arc.net/l/quote/tvrnmbwd)

To me this means, if a route is not found, if there is a fallback rewrite, that should _always_ apply, no matter how that not found is initiated. i.e., 
- Implicit 404 ✅  - As shown in the first example, if the next router resolves a 404, the rewrite applies.
- explicit 404 ❌  - In the second example, if we're in a dynamic route, but, per whatever lookup logic we do (in my case, api call to a headless CMS), if the dynamic path isn't resolvable and you call [`notFound()`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/functions/not-found), this bypasses the fallback rewrite and goes straight to the 404 page.

Similarly, this seems like a topic to potentially mention in the [Dynamic Routes doc page](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/routing/dynamic-routes)?—how to handle dynamic routes that are not found (i.e., `notFound()`, `rewrites`, `redirects`, etc...)

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 22.3.0: Mon Jan 30 20:39:46 PST 2023; root:xnu-8792.81.3~2/RELEASE_ARM64_T6020
  Available memory (MB): 32768
  Available CPU cores: 10
Binaries:
  Node: 20.10.0
  npm: 10.3.0
  Yarn: 1.22.22
  pnpm: 9.12.1
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.2-canary.6 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.2-canary.6).
  eslint-config-next: N/A
  react: 19.0.0-rc-1631855f-20241023
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-1631855f-20241023
  typescript: 5.3.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Runtime

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local), next build (local), next start (local)

### Additional context

I tested my reproduction in Next 15.x and 13.x w/ App Router, both have the issue. I suspect this is just an app router issue.

title: `NEXT_REDIRECT` internal error making it to the client

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Navigation
labels.description: Related to Next.js linking (e.g., <Link>) and navigation.

labels.name: Runtime
labels.description: Related to Node.js or Edge Runtime with Next.js.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://github.com/kevinmitch14/redirects2 ### To Reproduce Start application Click buttons Observe Network tab ### Current vs. Expected behavior With new changes introduced in https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/69945, it seems that the internal `NEXT_REDIRECT` error will now leak into client code, where before it did not. So basically with an action using `redirect()`, a `NEXT_REDIRECT` error will be thrown, to let next.js know that a redirect needs to happen. This will be handled, doing the redirect, and then the error will also now leak to the client code as of v15.0.0-canary.160. Even when this `NEXT_REDIRECT` error is caught in the try/catch block, the redirect will still have already been handled. So I don't really see the purpose of this internal error reaching the client in the first place. I was told to use `unstable_rethrow()` to "fix" this issue. So basically to rethrow the internal error that made it to client code, but the problem is, next.js already handled the redirect, and this error is serving no purpose on the client (i think). But anyway, I tried to use `unstable_rethrow()` and this results in 2 requests being made in the redirect process. The intended redirect process and then when `unstable_rethrow()` rethrows the error, it is causing another network request to fetch the RSC payload (which has already been fetched and rendered) > From https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/69945 - This allows the redirect to be handled in a single request rather than requiring a second request to fetch the RSC payload on the URL being redirected to. So what happens is AFAICT: 1. Invoke server action 2. Server action redirects 3. In the UI is redirected 4. The `NEXT_REDIRECT` error is caught in the catch block and rethrown 5. The payload for the redirect destination is requested again Whereas, if the `NEXT_REDIRECT` is simply swallowed on the client, only one request will be fired. ```tsx
{ try { e.preventDefault(); await action(); } catch (error) { unstable_rethrow(error); } }} >
``` **Swallowed Error** **Using unstable_rethrow** It looks like the commit that caused this regression is aiming at fixing issues with `useActionState`, but the reality is, this is a very new, not mature API. And many will not be touching it. Many are using for libraries such as react-hook-form, where onSubmit is used as opposed to the action prop. Here is another example: Here, this success toast will never fire, actually the error toast will fire. Previously, the success toast would fire, along with the redirect. And error toast would only fire when an error is thrown in the action (not internal errors) ```tsx
{ try { e.preventDefault(); await action(); toast("Success") } catch (error) { toast("Error") console.log(error); } }} >
``` Previous issue that was closed pretty quickly... https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/71740 ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: darwin Arch: arm64 Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.0.0: Fri Sep 15 14:41:43 PDT 2023; root:xnu-10002.1.13~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6000 Available memory (MB): 16384 Available CPU cores: 10 Binaries: Node: 22.8.0 npm: 10.8.2 Yarn: 1.22.19 pnpm: 8.15.1 Relevant Packages: next: 15.0.2-canary.5 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.2-canary.5). eslint-config-next: 15.0.1 react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021 react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021 typescript: 5.6.3 Next.js Config: output: N/A ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) Navigation, Runtime ### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) next dev (local), next build (local) ### Additional context _No response_

title: Dev with Turbo fails to parse CSS Modules :global

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Turbopack

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/jovial-kilby-t95gx5

### To Reproduce

1. Start the application in dev with turbo mode
2. See CSS source parsing error

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Expected the CSS Modules to work with the `:global` selector, applying the styles accordingly as per [their documentation](https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules/blob/master/docs/composition.md#exceptions). title: Typescript definitions don't exist for new `disableFontFamilyHashing` option in `next/font`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: TypeScript
labels.description: Related to types with Next.js.

labels.name: Font (next/font)
labels.description: Related to Next.js Font Optimization.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/eliasb-usafacts/nextjs-font-hashing-repro

### To Reproduce

1. Clone linked repo
2. Run `bun install`
3. Run `bun run build`

Build fails with TS error:
![Screenshot 2024-10-23 at 3 36 49 PM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/152c35b0-8e3f-4121-860f-97e16c5da672)


### Current vs. Expected behavior

#### Current Behavior
The `next/font` loader works correctly in dev mode, and the font is appropriately given a name that is not hashed. This is to say that the `disableFontFamilyHashing` setting is working correctly.

However, the option doesn't exist in `next/font`'s typescript definitions, and so typescript throws an error during type checking.

#### Expected Behavior
A typescript definition for disableFontFamilyHashing is present in `next/font`.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.5.0: Wed May  1 20:13:18 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.121.3~5/RELEASE_ARM64_T6030
  Available memory (MB): 36864
  Available CPU cores: 12
Binaries:
  Node: 20.13.1
  npm: 10.8.3
  Yarn: N/A
  pnpm: N/A
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1).
  eslint-config-next: 15.0.1
  react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Font (next/font), TypeScript

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next build (local)

### Additional context

I found out about this change from the https://nextjs.org/blog/next-15#other-changes section of the NextJS 15 announcement post.

This PR https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/53608 is where the feature was implemented, but from what I can tell it did not include any additions to the necessary typescript definitions.

title: Upgrading to Next v15.0.0 throws a directly accessed param warning

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/auth0-developer-hub/web-app_nextjs_javascript_hello-world

### To Reproduce

Download this project,
https://github.com/auth0-developer-hub/web-app_nextjs_javascript_hello-world
configure the local env on a free auth0 account or replace with next auth provider.

upgrade package with these dependencies
```
"@typescript-eslint/parser": "8.11.0",
"@auth0/nextjs-auth0": "3.5.0",
"axios": "1.7.7",
"eslint": "9.13.0",
"eslint-config-next": "15.0.0",
"next": "15.0.0",
"react": "18.2.0",
"react-dom": "18.2.0",
"swr": "2.2.5"
```

run the project, attempt to login or directly access the `/api/auth/login` route (or appropriate auth route).

This will result in the following error.

```
Error:  In route /api/auth/[auth0] a param property was accessed directly with `params.auth0`. `params` should be awaited before accessing its properties. Learn more: https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/sync-dynamic-apis
```


### Current vs. Expected behavior

Current:
```
Error:  In route /api/auth/[auth0] a param property was accessed directly with `params.auth0`. `params` should be awaited before accessing its properties. Learn more: https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/sync-dynamic-apis
```

Expected:
Handle error, consider cases where the param is accessed directly.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: linux
  Arch: x64
  Version: #202405300957~1726766035~22.04~4092a0e SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Thu S
  Available memory (MB): 15644
  Available CPU cores: 8
Binaries:
  Node: 20.17.0
  npm: 10.8.2
  Yarn: 1.22.22
  pnpm: 9.12.2
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.0 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.0).
  eslint-config-next: 15.0.0
  react: 18.2.0
  react-dom: 18.2.0
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Developer Experience, Pages Router

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local)

### Additional context

### Reproduction URL

`/api/auth/login`

### The issue

Next v15.0.0 now requires auth params to be awaited. Currently the handleAuth and handleLogin access the params directly, causing an error to be thrown by Next.

Similar [issue](https://github.com/nextauthjs/next-auth/issues/12092) logged and closed recently on next-auth repo.

title: Parallel Routes not working on Cloud Run in Next.js 15

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

labels.name: Parallel & Intercepting Routes
labels.description: Related to Parallel and/or Intercepting routes.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/aramikuto/nextjs-parallel-route-server-js-problem

### To Reproduce

1. Build the application and start the standalone server with the following command:
```bash
yarn build && cp -r .next/static .next/standalone/.next/ && node .next/standalone/server.js
```
2. Open the network inspector and navigate to the homepage at http://localhost:3000/ 
3. Note the URL of the chunk containing the parallel route.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

In Next.js 14, the @ symbol in the chunk URL is not encoded, appearing as:
http://localhost:3000/_next/static/chunks/app/@modal/page-5d9f089824f6dc9b.js

In Next.js 15.0.0 and 15.0.1-canary.1, the @ symbol is encoded as %40, so the URL looks like:
http://localhost:3000/_next/static/chunks/app/%40modal/page-e0360b9b769efb1a.js

When deployed to Cloud Run, this chunk becomes inaccessible because [Some encoded URL characters are decoded](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/known-issues#http2-iap) by Cloud Run. It seems Cloud Run decodes %40 back to @, but the standalone server on Next.js 15 responds with a 404 error for such requests.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: arm64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.6.0: Mon Jul 29 21:16:46 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.141.2~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8112
  Available memory (MB): 24576
  Available CPU cores: 8
Binaries:
  Node: 20.11.1
  npm: 10.2.4
  Yarn: 1.22.21
  pnpm: N/A
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.1-canary.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1-canary.1).
  eslint-config-next: N/A
  react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021
  typescript: 5.3.3
Next.js Config:
  output: standalone
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Parallel & Intercepting Routes

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Other (Deployed)

### Additional context

It seems this issue may have been introduced in PR #70256.

body: ### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://github.com/byytelope/tailwind4test ### To Reproduce 1. Start using `next dev` 2. See that the mono font is applied to the text, and font files are available when inspecting source. 3. Remove .next dir 4. Start using `next dev --turbo` 5. See that the default sans font is being used instead of the custom one, and no font files are bundled when inspecting source. ### Current vs. Expected behavior Web fonts loaded using next/font/google, and set up using the TailwindCSS v4 alpha do not seem to be bundled in when using turbopack for development. When using webpack with `next dev`, the font loads and seems to be bundled in properly. But when using turbopack with `next dev --turbo`, the font does not load and does not seem to be bundled in properly. This issue was reported before but was fixed for some by removing the `.next` directory and rebuilding. I can reproduce this issue reliably on both Safari 18.1 and Edge 130.0.2849.46 on macOS 18.1. ### Provide environment information ```bash Operating System: Platform: darwin Arch: arm64 Version: Darwin Kernel Version 24.1.0: Thu Oct 10 21:02:26 PDT 2024; root:xnu-11215.41.3~2/RELEASE_ARM64_T8122 Available memory (MB): 16384 Available CPU cores: 8 Binaries: Node: 22.9.0 npm: 10.8.3 Yarn: N/A pnpm: N/A Relevant Packages: next: 15.0.1-canary.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.1-canary.1). eslint-config-next: N/A react: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021 react-dom: 19.0.0-rc-69d4b800-20241021 typescript: 5.3.3 Next.js Config: output: N/A ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? title: Codemod upgrade script does not consider the absence of the "dev" script in the package.json

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://stackblitz.com/edit/nextjs-vewqbk?file=package.json

### To Reproduce

1. Open the repro and run `npx @next/codemod@canary upgrade latest`
2. It should throw 
```bash
npx @next/codemod@canary upgrade latest
  Detected installed versions:
  - React: v18.3.1
  - Next.js: v14.2.9
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'includes')
    at suggestTurbopack (/Users/prakharshukla/.npm/_npx/6a090669e21b4303/node_modules/@next/codemod/bin/upgrade.js:330:19)
    at runUpgrade (/Users/prakharshukla/.npm/_npx/6a090669e21b4303/node_modules/@next/codemod/bin/upgrade.js:152:15)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async Command.<anonymous> (/Users/prakharshukla/.npm/_npx/6a090669e21b4303/node_modules/@next/codemod/bin/next-codemod.js:51:9)
```

### Current vs. Expected behavior

The current behaviour is throwing error if the dev script if not found.
We should check for the nullability of the devScript before trying to run `.includes` on the string.

Code: 
```
async function suggestTurbopack(packageJson: any): Promise<void> {
  const devScript: string = packageJson.scripts['dev']
  if (devScript.includes('--turbo')) return

  const responseTurbopack = await prompts(
    {
      type: 'confirm',
      name: 'enable',
      message: 'Enable Turbopack for next dev?',
      initial: true,
    },
    { onCancel }
  )

```

title: Experimental PPR cannot be used in stable Next 15 (but mentioned in docs)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Related to Next.js' official documentation.

labels.name: linear: next
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Next.js team.

labels.name: Partial Prerendering (PPR)
labels.description: Related to Partial Prerendering.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/neoromantic/next-15-ppr-reproduction

### To Reproduce

1. Install last Next.js with create-next-app
2. Add  configuration to next.config.ts:

```
  experimental: {
    ppr: 'incremental',
  },
```
3. Run build or dev server

### Current vs. Expected behavior

If we run Next 15.0.0 stable with ppr enabled, we get [Canary Error](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/475bdb1f743bf0b3552b40f85b615d87f4ae4904/packages/next/src/server/config.ts#L247)

However, Docs suggests that it is supported: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/rendering/partial-prerendering with no mention of Canary versions.

It either should allow PPR in stable, or docs should be adjusted to not suggest using PPR in Next 15 (since it was released)

N/A
```

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/y2scxp

### To Reproduce

1. Make sure the CodeSandbox preview is running on `https://y2scxp-3000.csb.app`.

    - If not, run `npm run dev` in the CodeSandbox terminal.

2. Navigate to [page 1 (/pages1)](https://y2scxp-3000.csb.app/pages1) on the Pages Router using the URL bar.

3. Open up the Browser DevTools console and clear it.

4. Press the "Go to Pages Page 2" button. Note the URL updates but nothing is logged to the console.

---

5. Now navigate to [page 1 (/app1)](https://y2scxp-3000.csb.app/app1) on the App Router using the URL bar.

6. Clear the Browser DevTools console again.

7. Press the "Go to App Page 2" button. Note the URL updates AND we see `<NavigationEvents>` rerender and log the `currentPathQuery`.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Current Behavior:
- Using the native history API for navigation in Pages Router does **not** trigger a re-render of components that use `usePathname()` and remain mounted.

Expected Behavior:
- Using the native history API for navigation in Pages Router does trigger a re-render of components that use `usePathname()` and remain mounted.

### Provide environment information

```bash
See CodeSandbox link.
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Navigation, Pages Router

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local)

### Additional context

_No response_

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/vercel/next.js

### To Reproduce

I have a monorepo setup (tamagui) with 2 apps under `apps` and 5 shared modules under `packages`. Our Next app is located under `apps/next`. I am using module aliases via tsconfig paths. Our repo transpiles without issue, and our expo apps run without issue.

When running the app in the next dev server, I get a ton of error output. The messages all look like:
```
✘ [ERROR] Could not resolve "@my/utils/stringUtils/changeCase"

    ../../packages/ui/src/CheckBoxWithLabel.tsx:1:27:
      1 │ import { changeCase } from "@my/utils/stringUtils/changeCase"
        ╵                            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

What I have noticed is that the module aliases seem to work 1 level deep. But when we have `packages/ui` depending on `packages/utils` using module aliases, like the above, Next does not like it. I get the same output when exporting static web files.

What's really strange is that once Next finishes bundling, the app actually runs fine. It exports fine as well. But we're stuck with screens and screens of error output, which really slows down the bundling as well.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

I expect module aliases to work at any level.

### Provide environment information

```bash

title: CommonJS and ESM modules cause SSR and CSR rendering issues with react contexts when using a custom lib

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Webpack
labels.description: Related to Webpack with Next.js.

labels.name: Module Resolution
labels.description: Module resolution (CJS / ESM, module resolving).

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/datrycs/nextjs-library-esm-cjs-ssr-issues

### To Reproduce

1. Navigate to `sample-lib` folder
2. Install deps using `yarn install`
3. Use `yarn build` and `yalc publish` to publish the package
4. Navigate to `nextjs-project` folder
5. Use `yalc add sample-lib` in `nextjs-project` to make the published package available
6. Install deps using `yarn install`
7. Start the environment using `yarn dev`
8. Navigate to http://localhost:3000/example_with_lib to see the error
9. Navigate to http://localhost:3000/example_without_lib to see it working
10. Use `export ANALYZE=true` and restart the dev server so you can inspect webpack bundles



### Current vs. Expected behavior

Currently, we are trying to use @commercelayer/react-components as part of an internal custom library. When we bundle the library with CJS and ESM exports and reuse it in our nextjs project, SSR fails with context not found issues. We think this has to do with CJS/ESM module resolution on the server side when doing the initial SSR rendering. 

The example repo includes two cases where we use a Commercelayer component called LineItemsContainer. LineItemsContainer provides a context that is consumed by a different Commercelayer component further down the tree.

The working case imports LineItemsContainer directly from the node_modules folder and works correctly in SSR and on the client.

The error case imports a custom component from a self hosted npm package that wraps LineItemsContainer as a child, but for some reason SSR and CSR fail in this case. The expected behavior is that the error case also renders without an error.

Expected rendering of the http://localhost:3000/example_with_lib page:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f222e8dc-3ca0-4e34-bc44-53454cfe5aea)

Actual rendering of http://localhost:3000/example_with_lib page:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/05a8e392-ade0-42b4-9d76-f763b5488224)

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/thevisioner/next-turbo-css-modules-value-issue-reproduction

### To Reproduce

1. Start the application in development using the --turbo flag (next dev --turbo).
2. Open the browser and inspect the Network tab in the DevTools (CSS files).
3. Look for the `page.css` file with the `LayoutExample` class.
4. Pay attention to the `@media` declaration.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

In development using the --turbo flag (next dev --turbo) the CSS output contains the declaration, but the value (named 'compact') is not replaced with the actual value: `@media compact {}`.

However, in case without the --turbo flag (next dev) and in case of production build (next build) the value is replaced with the actual value: `@media (max-width: 37.4375em) {}`.

title: CSS not chunked per page - resulting in loading too much CSS

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Webpack
labels.description: Related to Webpack with Next.js.

labels.name: Performance
labels.description: Anything with regards to Next.js performance.

labels.description: Module resolution (CJS / ESM, module resolving).

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/joostmeijles/css-chunk-not-per-page

### To Reproduce

1. pnpm run build
2. pnpm run start
3. Visit http://localhost:3000/ and inspect the CSS file

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Currently CSS file contains:
```
.page_topLevel__iX_Qv {
    width: 10
}

.Component_component__VGHKW {
    width: 20
}

.page_test__Mq0km {
    height: 30
}
```

Expected to contain:
```
.page_topLevel__iX_Qv {
    width: 10
}

.Component_component__VGHKW {
    width: 20
}
```

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: win32
  Arch: x64
  Version: Windows 10 Enterprise
  Available memory (MB): 32472
  Available CPU cores: 16
Binaries:
  Node: 18.20.2
  npm: 10.5.0
  Yarn: 1.22.19
  pnpm: 9.9.0
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.0.0-rc.1 // Latest available version is detected (15.0.0-rc.1).
  eslint-config-next: 14.2.15
  react: 18.3.1
  react-dom: 18.3.1
  typescript: 5.6.3
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```


### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Module Resolution, Performance, Webpack

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next build (local), Vercel (Deployed)

### Additional context

CSS only present in another page is exposed to unrelated pages. This leads in larger applications to huge (and many) CSS files. Which is bad for performance, e.g. LCP is impacted due to loading CSS.

When you remove the `Component` from `app/test/page.tsx` the CSS does no longer wrongly contain the `.page_test__Mq0km` CSS class.

I tested against 14.2.15 and 15.0.0-rc.1 with the same result.

labels.name: bug

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/johnslemmer/video-muted-bug

### To Reproduce

deployed at https://video-muted-bug.vercel.app/ and ready to demonstrate.

Steps to recreate:

- Easily seen by loading the home page (you will see a video auto play and be muted)
- click the link to go to the about page
- click the link to come back to home page
  - the video will now be auto playing but also playing sound
  - if you check the elements in DevTools you will see the `muted` attribute no
    longer exists on the video element. Which feels like a Router Cache issue.

Code is pretty simple, the weird `innerHTML` set is done to show how not having
`muted` cached properly can lead to undesirable audio playing on, for all
intents and purposes, what was a muted video from the developer's perspective.

### Current vs. Expected behavior

Here is a gif showing the current  behavior.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/35fb2765-c423-432a-a0f4-2b3574276056

Expected would be that `muted` would be preserved.

title: Bug Report: Type Error in API Route Exports in Next.js

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: TypeScript
labels.description: Related to types with Next.js.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/HyeokjaeLee/briend/blob/bug/1.0.0/src/utils/createApiRoute.ts

### To Reproduce

Create an API route using the App Router (src/app/api/auth/unlink-account/route.ts).

Define a function with any HTTP method (e.g., POST, GET).

Pass a second parameter to the function.

Try to build the project.

The following type errors appear during the build:

Type "Promise<unknown>" is not a valid type for the function's second argument.
Type "{}" is not a valid type for the function's second argument.
Type "undefined" is not a valid type for the function's second argument. Expected "RouteContext", got "undefined".

### Current vs. Expected behavior

**Current Behavior:**
When defining an API route, the second parameter of the exported function throws type errors like Promise<unknown>, {}, or undefined being invalid.
RouteContext type is expected but cannot be found or imported, causing the build to fail.

**Expected Behavior:**
The second parameter of the API route functions should correctly accept the appropriate RouteContext type (or equivalent) without throwing type errors.
The RouteContext type should be importable or properly inferred by Next.js.

### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform:  mac
  Architecture: arm m2
  Version: 15.0(24A335)
Binaries:
  Bun: 1.1.26
Relevant Packages:
  "next": "15.0.0-rc.1"
  "@types/node": "^20.16.11"
  "@types/react": "npm:types-react@19.0.0-rc.1"

  "@types/react-transition-group": "^4.4.11"

title: Next.js Image component always loads image as 3840px

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue was opened via the bug report template.

labels.name: Image (next/image)
labels.description: Related to Next.js Image Optimization.

body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/7djqzn ``` import Image from "next/image"; import imageShapes from "../public/unsplash.jpg"; export default function Home() { return (
); } ``` ### To Reproduce 1. Start the application in development mode 2. Visit the home page 3. Inspect the image 4. In the inspector, it's shown that the image is currently using the 3840px version as seen in the img "src" attribute. 6. This is the src of the img 7. src="/_next/image?url=%2F_next%2Fstatic%2Fmedia%2Funsplash.549710ac.jpg&w=3840&q=75"> 8. The "w=3840" on the img src is being set automatically. I'm not sure how that value is computed. 9. The code for this page is located in app/page.tsx ### Current vs. Expected behavior I'm using the Next.js component to display an image, but I’m running into a problem where the image is always set to a width of 3840px. I have the "sizes" attribute set to 1px, but it doesn't seem to take effect. Despite setting sizes="1px", the image URL generated has w=3840, which is much larger than expected. Here’s a screenshot showing the image using the 3840px version. According to the Next.js documentation:https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/api-reference/components/image#width, the width and height for statically imported images don't need to be set. Does anyone know why the image is defaulting to such a large size? How can I ensure it uses a smaller version based on the sizes attribute? Any help would be greatly appreciated! ### Provide environment information ```bash google chrome ``` ### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) Image (next/image) ### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply) next dev (local), next build (local), next start (local), Vercel (Deployed) ### Additional context _No response_
